titleStmt.title: John Quincy Adams Diary Digital Project

div.p: 1. IV:30. Sunday.

Morning service at the Presbyterian church Stranger with Mr Fowler—from Revelations 22.16–17— Visit from Mr Catlin, to ask for a Letter— Coll. Thayer—doubtful if he returns to West-Point— St. John’s—P.M. Mr Dana.— 3d. Sunday after Trinity— James 4:14— Struggle to redeem diary arrears.
2. IV. Monday.

Committee of Manufactures. present Adams, Naylor, Slade—Webster— No Quorum— H.R.U.S. Call for Petitions superseded at Whittlesey’s motion— I yield the floor for Reports of Committees— Boon’s Motion to supersede the Morning hour for the rest of the Session failed 101. to 54— Its object to silence me, on the Texas question— Army Bill— Reconsideration refused— Bill forced through by the previous question 112 to 80— Borden, Cushing, Fletcher, Grennell, Lincoln, Parmenter and Phillips voting for it— Adams, Briggs, W. B. Calhoun, and Hastings against it— Reed was against it, but did not vote— Rice Garland moves to amend the title— The Harbour Bill—till the recess and again till 10 at Night when the Committee of the whole on the Union J. M. Mason in the Chair reported it with many amendments to the House— I skirmished after the recess, with Cambreleng— Gave G. Catlin a Letter to T. Aspinwall. Wise, introduced to me Coll. Ray, going to London, and wants a Letter— Conversation with Menefee—who had been on a frolic down the Potowmac with Jenifer— Books—Hobbes—Locke—Rousseau. Mandeville Sidney—Bolingbroke—Burke—Hume, Lingard— When I came home I found Isaac Hull Adams here—from Quincy
3. IV:15. Tuesday

Call at Bank of Washington— H.R.US— Several interpositions—Goode—Howard objects—to reply. I resume the Constitutional Argument against the annexation of Texas— Jefferson’s opinions on that of Louisiana— Richmond Enquirer—the Semi-colon and comma—charge upon me— My opinions and conduct on the acquisition of Louisiana— Hour expires New revenue Bill from the Senate— Cambreleng’s short Speech. Previous Question lost. Duncan of Ohio— Recess and Duncan again— Previous Question again lost— Calls of the House— Many amendments lost— Public funds not to be used for banking—101 to 101. Speaker’s casting vote carries it— Jenifer asks me to move
a reconsideration which I decline— Adjourn after 10— Excessive heat— Letters to B. Lundy and G. W. Adams.

4. IV. Wednesday— Independence day— H.R.U.S. Morning hour. Howard objects to any intrusion upon my time, that may encroach upon his to answer me— My Speech in S.U.S. on the Louisiana Treaty— Resolutions offered in Senate. Conferences with Mr Madison— Annexation by act of Congress.— Comma-ites, and Semi-Colonites— Slavery— Reply to Elmore— Insane ravings. His apology— Hour expires— Waddy Thompson’s question—not allowed— Grennell moves to suspend the rules to take up the Senate Bill against duelling—rejected.— Senate sub-treasury Bill N. 3. sent back emasculated 2d. Section struck out— Old Harbour Bill debated— Cambreleng’s Statement of expenditures, four millions motion to adjourn at 2. failed— Recess and Letters to G. W. Adams and S. A. Turner— New motion to adjourn failed— Harbour bill passed— Evans and Fairfield— Harbour bill passed and reconsideration refused— Message P.U.S. voluminous Mexican Correspondence. Howard moves a select Committee of 3. to select the papers to be printed— I move that they be laid on the table and printed. question divided— Robertson moves to lay motion to print on the table— Carried 103 to 80— Robertson afterwards gave notice of a motion to reconsider— Steam-boat and Express mail Bills— Adjourned at 7. Walk home— Visits from Govr and Treasurer Campbell— James Barbour.
5— IV. Thursday.

Pratt Cary here with de factivo papers for an application for increase of pension— He goes to procure further papers. Daveis and Cushing here Resolutions of Senate yesterday concerning the North Eastern boundary— Comee. of foreign Relations to offer similar Resolutions in H.R.— Comee. of Manufactures. Adams, Naylor, Slade, Tillinghast, Webster— Chairman directed to move the House that the Committee be discharged from the further consideration of all the matters referred to them— H.R.U.S— Howard declares I shall not allow other members to occupy parts of the morning hour—smart altercation— I proceed. Slavery— Report of the Comee. of H.R. of the State of Mississippi— I read extracts. comment I then assume hypothetically that the
system of the Executive Administration from 4. March 1829. towards Mexico has been duplicity to breed a War with Mexico, to accomplish the annexation of Texas to this Union— Review the Relations with Mexico,—during my Administration— First proposals to purchase Texas ill-received— Poinsett—expiration of the hour The Senate’s 3d. sub-treasury Bill, after various proposed amendment’s, passed by the Previous Question discarding John Campbells proviso, that the public money shall not be used for Banking. Robertson offers certain Resolutions for reorganizing the Public Land sale system— Rules not suspended— Recess— Elmore moves suspension of the rules for me to proceed— Dromgoole—rules not suspended— Indian Annuity—Bill— Fortification Bill— West Point Academy Bill— Harbour Bill—recess.— Harbour Bill again Casey instead of Connor in the Chair— No Quorum reported to the House— I asked to take up the Bills reported by the Committee of Manufactures remitting duties on iron for Steamboats— Cambreleng objects.— Question upon laying aside Bills in Committee of the whole.— Indian Appropriation Fortification, West Point Academy, and Bill to pay for the Books furnished to members passed in Committee and through the House— New Harbour bill debated till near 10. O’Clock P.M—when the Comee. rose and the House adjourned.
6. IV:30. Friday

HR.U.S— Morning hour 14th. day. Texas review of the propositions made to the Mexican Government for the purchase of Texas—Torrens—Clay—Poinsett, Van Buren—Anthony Butler—Poinsett’s recall— Succession of documents from N. 42— Dr Mayo’s Letter. hour expires— Howard enquires if I should not finish now, whether he can answer me hereafter— Speaker says the House must decide— I said that Howard and not I had the command of the Time of the House— Steam boat Bill from the Senate with Webster’s amendment—adopted— Robertson’s restriction upon Boats navigating within a State rejected— Cazeau’s Bill— Laid on the table— Medical Society’s Bill— Petrikin’s objection to the M.D’s— Boon’s preference of an old woman with her herbs— Aristocratic Bill, passed Falmouth and Alexandria Rail-road Bill laid on the table Pre-emption Bill—recess—

P.M— Reports of Committees— F. Thomas, from judiciary Committee moves to discharge the Comee of the whole from the consideration of the penal Bill vs. U.S. Bank. Wise objects that the Judiciary Comee. are functi-Officio on that Bill— Speaker decides Thomas to be in order— Comee. of the whole discharged.— Parris premature for the previous question. Prentiss obtains the floor against the Bill— My question of order.— Wise follows Prentiss— Then Jenifer whom after 10. P.M I left speaking— I saw the Bill would be forced through by the Previous Question, and was overcome with heat and weariness— The house after screwing the bill through adjourned just before Midnight— Committee of Manufactures had been at my motion discharged from the further Consideration of all matters referred to them.
7. V:30. Saturday

Comee. of Manufactures—no Meeting. I alone there— H.R.U.S— Morning hour. 15th. day— Texas.— I read A. Jackson’s Letter to W. Fulton 10. Decr. 1830. Howard’s Agitation— His Letter to W. Fulton, and Fulton’s answer— He gives them to me to be communicated to the House. Dromgoole moves suspension of the rules to answer me— Refused— Comee. of 3. to select the last Mexican Documents for publication— Supplement to the army Bill passed by previous question— Frauds on public Lands and Choctaw pre-emptions— Recess— I visited Dr Henry Perrine at the chamber of the Comee of Agriculture, and examined his tropical plants and the fibrous leaves of the Aloes.— Evening Session— Small Note Bill in District of Columbia; passed by previous question— Indian Annuity Bill. Bill to sell the Bonds due from the Bank of the United States. New-York fire Bill— Western Opposition. Chambers— Underwood— My warm tempered support of the Bill— Harbour Bill, Post-route Bill, Fortification Bill— West-Point Academy— Bill debated by fits and starts— Duncan called to order, directed to take his Seat, and the House refuse him permission to proceed. Petrikin the same—for saying 20000 dollars is the price of the Kentucky delegation— At 20 Minutes past Midnight I left the House and came home, sick at heart, exhausted and faint with weariness and excessive heat—knowing that nothing further would be done by the House to any useful purpose—
8. VI:30. Sunday.

Just before 8 O’Clock this morning my Granddaughter Mary-Louisa came in to my chamber and told me the flag of the House of Representatives was still flying They sat all night—had a call of the House and adjourned about 8 this morning. Lewis day a Negro 54 years old a Slave of John West Minor living in this district on the Virginia side of the Potomack, came to enquire if I could obtain for him relief or money— One of 15 four of whom his master has already sold to go to Georgia—and the rest are to be sold in a few days— I could afford him no relief, but commended him to mercy and Patience— He was broken hearted— At St. John’s Church. Mr Hawley— Read the service for the 4th Sunday after Trinity; baptized a boy and preached from Luke 8.24. After dinner Mr Wiltberger read the service and preached from John 3.18. on the crime of unbelief.— Evening visits from Mr C. S. Daveis of Maine, to take leave—from Mrs Hellen; her daughter Adele Her Admirer Mr Moody, of Mobile Alabama, originally from Saco Maine and from Mr John Pope—whose brother Nathl. is down with a fever.
9. IV:30. Monday

Second Session of the 25th. Congress closed— The House of Representations adjourned yesterday morning to meet this morning a 9— B. Howard enquired of the Speaker whether I was to continue my Speech this Morning. The Speaker said the last day of the Session, all the ordinary rules of the House were superseded— Bell made some remarks upon a vote yesterday at the call of the House to excuse him for absence on payment of fees— This led to a discussion of two hours and sundry propositions; to revoke all the censorial votes upon absentees yesterday Morning at the call— I moved an amendment to Bell’s Resolution, one to rescind all resolutions of censure, and all orders for payment of fees by members for absence on the call of the House on the morning. The members who had passed these resolutions took this as casting a reflection upon them— Wise moved a reconsideration of the
Resolutions of censure which had been moved by him; whereupon Bell withdrew his resolution whereby mine, moved as an amendment to his fell of course. Wise called for the previous question upon the reconsideration of his first resolution of censure which was carried and on reconsideration the resolution was rescinded— He then moved a reconsideration of his second Resolution, which required that sixteen Members whom the Sergeant at arms had found at the Railway Cars starting for Baltimore, and who in defiance of his summons still went their way, should be called to answer for their contumacy at the reassembling of the House, and he moved the Previous Question at the same time— A question of order was made whether two Questions could be moved by a member, at once— The Speaker mirum dictu, decided that they could; and the House on appeal sustained the decision— The reconsideration prevailed, but the House refused to revoke the resolution against the contumacious members— I then moved my resolution to rescind all resolutions of censure and all orders for payment of fees for absence at the call of the House on the Sabbath, and moved the previous Question, which occasioned a shout of laughter in the House— It was carried and my Resolution was rejected by yeas and nays 43 to 90.— Afterwards I appealed to the good nature of the House to pass a Resolution remitting the payment of fees, which had been ordered— M’Kennan offered the Resolution and it was adopted— The 16th. and 17th. joint rules of the two Houses were suspended, to receive from the Senate a joint Resolution with an appropriation, to print Mr Madison’s papers—to pass it in Committee of the whole, turn it into a Bill, and pass it through all its Stages; and the Senate concurred in the suspension of the Rules, in changing the Resolution to a Bill, and the President approved the Bill, and it became a law. All this was done in half an hour, without opposition or debate and proved how easy it would have been to pass 30. more bills of great importance without a Sunday morning Session, and without sitting above an hour longer this day.— The usual communications between the two houses, and between them and the President passed, and both Houses adjourned about noon— I rode home and stopped on my way at the Office to arrange with Mr Gales, about the printing of the remainder of my 15 days Speech— At home, disqualified by the heat from all possible labour—looking over the Notes of the reporters A Stansbury and W. F. Otis— Stansbury came into Gales’s Office, and Gales paid him off while I was there.
10. Tuesday IV:30

About Sunrise I rode to the Potowmac, to my old bathing place beneath the bluff between the Mouth of the Tyber, and the Bridge, where I bathed and swam about a quarter of an hour. It was the first river bath that I have been able to take this Season, and seemed to give me new life— There were as used formerly to be a number of other bathers there, and some with horses, all young men, except myself. National Intelligencer, publishes my Speech of 30. June and of 26. June under date of 3. July— Walk to the Office—pointed out the mistake both to Gales and Seaton— Overpowered by the heat—remainder of the day wholly idle.
11. IV:15. Wednesday

Morning bath, and swim again at the Potowmack— I enter upon my 72d. year— Sent for a hack in the middle of the day— Took back the books which I had out of the Congress Library, excepting two that I could not find. call at the Bank of Washington, and deposited there the Speaker’s check for 651:20— Family preparing for departure— Report of Committee of Foreign Affairs, and Minority report of C. Cushing published in this day’s National Intelligencer—with the advertisement of my Texas Speech in pamphlet— I revised at the Intelligencer Office the proof slips of the portions to be published in the paper of to-morrow— Mr Walker called and agreed to send for my horses to morrow, to send them to be kept in Loudoun County Virginia during the Summer— Mr Moody came and tendered his services to escort the Ladies on their journey—he proposing to go to morrow on his visit to his native State of Maine— Campbell and Thomas Frye were here this Evening
12. IV. Thursday.

At 6. this morning, my wife, with Mary, and her two daughters, attended by Margaret Nelson, and Thomas Dunphy departed in the Cars for Baltimore, to return to our home at Quincy— I went with them to the Cars and saw them off— Mrs Adams received a Note from Mr Moody, of excuses for being so much indisposed and overpowered by the heat and fatigue of his journey from Mobile to this place, that he finds himself unable to go on— Mr Brodhead one of the Members of the House from the State of New-York, went on in the same Cars— Walking home I stopped and purchased a Trunk, at a Trunk-maker’s shop— Just before Noon Isaac Hull Adams, came
in just from Baltimore, where he had met my wife and family, just arrived there— Hull is employed by the Chesapeake and Ohio Canal Company, under the direction of Coll. Abert, in civil-engineering— He is now sent down to procure money to pay the workmen— Expects to return to-morrow. He promised to come and dine with me, and to come for a lodging this Evening, but did not— Mr Thomas B. Johnson, came from Woodleigh and dined with me, but insisted upon returning this Evening. He went off accordingly in a Hack about 9. O’Clock— The day like many preceding it was intensely hot; and the atmosphere was very little refreshed by a thunder-shower which came on about Sunset— My remarks on the 22d. and 28th. of June were published in the National Intelligencer of this day.
13. V. Friday.

I. H. Adams came again this morning, and took leave; having received the money for which he came— He left the City this afternoon to return to his Station— I was employed the whole day in revising the Notes of the Reporters of my Speech, and supplying passages which in the confusion of the House they had not been able to report— Neither Gales nor Seaton, account for the fact that no report of my remarks on the 23d. of June has been furnished them by Stansbury, who was the reporter for that day— He went off to Philadelphia, on the day of the adjournment of Congress and left an unfinished report of what I had said on Saturday the 7th. instt. he sent from Philadelphia, the conclusion of his Notes for that day, and I have them to revise— I also settled a number of Accounts this day— At the Bank of Washington—and called at Morgan’s, Boteler and Donn’s and Kinchy’s— I called also at the Office of Niles’s Register, and he promised to republish my Speech as revised in the pamphlet to be published by Gales and Seaton— I had intended to leave the City on my return home to-morrow Morning; but found it impossible to get through my preparations particularly for the publication of my Speech— Languishing with heat and much disqualified for writing— At the dusk of Evening, I called at the President’s House to take leave of him, but he was gone out to ride— Dr Thomas was here; and said that the intelligence from Dr Huntt was rather favourable— Mr Frye was also here, and spoke of certain repairs desired by Dr. Huntt on the house which he rents from me—
14. V. Saturday

Call at the War Department, and left with Mr Poinsett a letter fromof Marblehead respecting the claims of sundry widows there, for revolutionary Pensions— He promised to write to me on the subject. At the National Intelligencer Office, where I returned the Notes of the Reporters of my morning hour discourses on the 5th. 6th. and 7th. of July— Seaton told me he had written to Stansbury, to send me his Notes of my Speech on the 23d. of June; but I think it best not to trust to him for them— The publication of my whole Speech in pamphlet was advertised by my direction in the National-Intelligencer yesterday.— I received a Note from Mrs Madison mentioning that she was about going to Virginia, and requesting me to return the Manuscripts of Mr Madison, which had been lent me to read. I answered her note immediately informing her that I had returned them all to her Son Mr Todd, several weeks since. In the evening I received from her a second note, apologizing for the first— After Sunset I called to see Mrs W. S. Smith, and found Mrs Thomas Munroe, and Mrs Constant Freeman with her— Mr Smith has lost his place for retaining a percentage on his accounts as paying Officer of the Department is Now at New-York— She said he had written that he should be here to-morrow, but she would give him another week— Mrs Smith said her brother had stopped and passed the Night on Thursday at her house— He sent a boy early this morning to enquire whether I proposed to go off on Monday— I sent for answer probably not till Tuesday Morning.
15. IV:30 Sunday.
Campbell Archibald

At the Presbyterian Church this morning heard a young man named Stevenson from Acts 17.11. [“]These were more noble than those in Thessalonica, in that they received the word with all readiness of mind, and searched the Scriptures daily, whether those things were so.”— The words underscored were the text, and the Discourse was an earnest and vehement exhortation to search the Scriptures daily— Having been for about fifty years deeply impressed with the sense of that duty, the excessive zeal of the preacher to inculcate it upon his
hearers was rather irksome to me— After dinner, at St. John’s Church the service was performed by Mr Meade, a son of Bishop Meade of Virginia, who had preached there this morning— The prayers were for the 5th. Sunday after Trinity, and the Sermon, from Hebrews 6:1. “Therefore leaving the principles of the doctrine of Christ, let us go on unto perfection”: the words underscored—the remainder of the verse is—“not laying again the foundation of repentance from dead works, and of faith toward God.” This is a remarkable text, and deserves well to be treated in connection with the preceding and subsequent Chapters—to the tenth inclusive— The whole being an argument addressed specially to the Jews, to prove the superiority of the new to the old Testament, and that the Mosaic dispensation was entirely superseded by that of Christianity. Mr Meade, considered the text rather in its separate sense, as a general precept of the gospel to all Christians to go on unto perfection—The Sermon was well written; but its doctrine was severe gloomy and atrabilious— And the preacher had a sickly, pain-cankered countenance— There was nothing lovely either in his matter or manner— Campbell was here towards Evening— At dusk I called at Mrs Madison’s house to take leave of her, but she had walked out— I was occupied all the remainder of the day in drawing up a statement of my remarks and of the proceedings in the House of Representatives on the 23d. of June; which I had yet not time to finish.
16. IV:15. Monday.

Finished the statement of facts, and report of proceedings in the House of Representatives on the 23d. of June, to be published in the National Intelligencer— Morning visits from Mr Fowler the Minister of the Presbyterian Church with Mr Stevenson, who preached there yesterday Morning— I called at the Department of State, and returned the Trial of Smith and Ogden, which W. S. Smith had borrowed there for me last March— Mr Forsyth asked me if I could lend him a copy of Mellish’s map of the edition of 1. Jany 1818 being that upon which the Florida Treaty of 22. Feby. 1819 was drawn up and to which it refers— I said I had I believed no copy of it; but that the identical copy of the Map used for the
description of the boundaries in the Treaty should be in the Department— He said they wanted it for the execution of a boundary Treaty lately concluded with Texas— That they had copies of Mellish’s Map of 1. Jany 1816 and of 1820. but they did not agree with the Descriptions in the Treaty— I took to Mr Lewis Johnson, a Letter for him received a few days since from Mr John Otis of West-Boston Barnstable, with enclosures; and I left with Mr Seaton at the National Intelligencer my Statement of the proceedings in the House on the 23d. of June and revised the proof slips of the Report to be published to-morrow Morning of my remarks on the 29th of June 3d. and 4th. of July. I gave directions that two copies of each tri-weekly paper that shall contain the remaining parcels of my Discourse, be sent to me at Quincy.— It was past 5. O’Clock when I got home to dine. Mr Frye was here after dinner and I gave him the key of my wine-cellar— The Evening was consumed in packing my trunks, of which I concluded to take two, and one blue chest N. 9. with Books to send round by Water.
17. IV. Tuesday—
From Washington to Baltimore— Philadelphia.

Hack took me, with William Wilkinson to the Cars— He belongs to Mrs Sarah Whetcroft—dismissed him with a Certificate— At 6. Started in the Cars, and reached Baltimore at 8— Waited there till 1/2 past 9. Mr Hall gave me a pocket book of his brother, Professor Hall who had lost it, and gone for Philadelphia this morning in the Cars which departed this morning at 6—requesting me to call at N. 102. Chesnut Street Philadelphia, at a boarding House kept by Miss Bail— Henry Johnson of Louisiana, was a passenger with me from Washington to Baltimore; where he is to embark for N. Orleans. The Louisiana election has gone all for the whigs— Governor Roman both branches of the Legislature—and for Congress. E. T. White, now Governor, Rice Garland, and Chinn— White comes in place of H. Johnson, who was not a Candidate— Cars from Baltimore very thin— J. L. Hudson, a Navy Officer, going upon the exploring expedition— Uncommonly obliging and attentive—claimed an old acquaintance which I am ashamed to have forgotten. 36 Miles to Havre de Grace— Large and pleasant family, landed at Newport 30 Miles to Wilmington Stop ten minutes to dine about 2.
Intense heat and a cooling shower— Cars stop 3 Miles short of Philadelphia— Rail-road yet unfinished— Transferred to shabby Stages— Land in Market Street 1/2 past 4. P.M— Take lodging at United States Hotel— Chamber up three pair of Stairs— Went immediately to Miss Bail’s 102 Chesnut Street, and delivered to Professor Hall his Pocket-book— Isaac Munroe of Baltimore, his wife, and Miss Hall a sister of the professor, are in company with him— Mr Munroe returns to Baltimore to-morrow. The rest are going Northward— Went to J. Sergeant’s— His wife, and two of the younger daughters there— After tea, he walked with me to N. Biddle’s— He had come home from the Bank with a head-ache; was in his chamber, and could not see me; but sent me word he had hoped to see me to-morrow, and for several days.— Walked then with Sergeant to Dr. Mease’s, but he was not at home— I went to apologize for not having answered his Letter of invitation to me, and my family to spend the Evening with him when we should come to Philadelphia, on our way home— Sergeant accompanied me to the door of my lodgings.— The Heat continues intense.
18. IV. Wednesday.
From Philadelphia to New-York— L.I. Sound.

Up at 4. A.M—by a call of emotion, which continued very troublesome the whole day— At 6. I took the Steam boat for Bordentown, still accompanied by Mr Hudson, whose kind attentions to me did not cease, and who when I told him I scarcely knew how to thank him for them adequately, said that my father had been the father of the Navy— He says the exploring expedition will sail by the 10th. of August— The Steamboat was crowded beyond all example— I verily believe there were 500 passengers in her. Dr Mease was one of the first whom I found on board— He landed at Bristol— Sergeant after leaving me last Evening, had found him at the Athenaeum, where he told me he had no doubt the Dr. was— Sergeant told him of the visit we had just paid to his house, and my object in going there; and so the Dr said he had concluded his best way to have the conversation with me, which had been the purpose of his invitation was to go down with me this morning as far as Bristol— The Doctor’s conversation is always pleasant and interesting. But his present object was to shew me an original Letter from General Washington all in his own hand-writing, and thanking the
Ladies of Philadelphia, for their patriotic services in 1780— He said there was a regular town meeting of Ladies at that time, and sundry proceedings by them to be found in Hall and Sellers’s paper of that time— He promised to send me a copy of General Washington’s Letter— W. B. Lewis was also in the Boat and introduced to me Mr Papineau, the expatriated and proscribed Canadian Insurgent, with whom I had much conversation, and told me that he had heretofore visited my father— He spoke cautiously of Canadian Affairs, and said that although he was banished on pain of death from Lower Canada, he was free to go to any other part of the British dominions, even to upper Canada— Mr Elmore, the member of the House from South-Carolina, with his wife and several children, were in the boat—going with the children of Mr Rhett to Litchfield in Connecticut—to spend the Summer there— And Dr Linn—Senator from Missouri, with his wife and one or two children— Dr. and Mrs Linn with both of whom I had some casual conversation gave me a very kind and cordial invitation to visit them at St. Genevieve in Missouri, where they reside— 1/2 past 2. New-York where after seeing my two trunks transferred from the Amboy boat to the Narragansett Steamer, Captain Child lying at the same Slip, Mr Hudson took leave of me— I walked into the City— Stop’d at a Barber’s shop and was shaved.— Then at the Astor House where at the ordinary were about 150 men at dinner— Took an empty chair, and found myself between Mr Hedge of Plymouth and a Stranger— Printed Bill of fare; French Cook, woodcocks, Snipes, Jellies, Tarts, and Champagne— Mr and Mrs Sidney Brooks are gone to Boston— I was obliged to leave the Table and hasten through a heavy shower of rain to the Narragansett which left the wharf at 5. P.M, speeding her passage for Providence— I preferred this to the Boat for Stonington; preferring with this Summer weather 48 miles of Steamboat Navigation from Stonington to Providence to the Rail-road ride of the same distance— The only old acquaintance whom I met as a fellow passengers here was Captain Reilly once the Shipwrecked captive of the Arab of the desart— Afterwards the Settler of the West, and member of the Legislature of Ohio, and now again for the last year the navigator of the Ocean, trading with the Empire of Morocco, for coarse duty-free wool. He has recently returned from a voyage to Tangier, and is going to endeavour to dispose of his Cargo at Boston.
19. III–45— Thursday.

I was roused by my indisposition about Midnight in the Steamer, and for the remnant of the Night had no sleep— There was a squall in the Night: but otherwise the weather was fine; and the passage, the shortest I ever made— At four this morning, 11 hours after our departure from New-York, sundry of our Passengers were landed at Newport, and others were taken in— At six, we landed at Providence, where the Passengers who came by the Stonington rail-road had but just arrived, and were waiting for us in the Cars— We came on immediately, and at nine of the morning, just sixteen hours from New-York I alighted at the Rail-way Depot, below the bottom of the Common— I had my two Trunks laden upon a Hack with the name of the Marlborough Hotel upon it, and deposited at that House, where I breakfasted— A great revolution has occurred in that establishment, since I dined there in 1835 with poor Alexander Townsend, then its proprietor, and whose melancholy death so soon afterwards ensued— It is now a religious and temperance House, and I found the Gentleman’s Parlour, with a central table covered with Bibles, Prayer-books and Psalm-books— Upon the ground adjoining the House where formerly stood the Stable, there now stands a Chapel—the officiating Minister at which is Mr Fitch— After breakfast I went to my Son’s Office in Court-Street; and found a notice on his door that he is in Town on Tuesday’s and Fridays till 1. P.M. Then I went to Elm Street and engaged a passage in the Quincy Stage this afternoon, with directions to Mr Gillett to take me up at the Marlborough Hotel— I next went to my Son’s House N 3. Hancock Avenue, but found it shut up— Called at Mr Frothingham’s, and was engaged by him and Mrs Frothingham to dine— At Governor Everett’s but found a notice on the door “out of Town”— At Mr James H. Foster’s—where I saw Mrs Foster and their three daughters— Met him afterwards in the Street and he went with me to the Marlborough Hotel— At 2. I went and dined with Mr Frothingham— At 4. returned to the Marlborough Hotel, where Gillett soon took me up and landed me before 6. at my house in Quincy— Here, I found my wife, and family, and my Son, his wife and children all in comfortable Health, and it seemed to me like an entrance into Paradise— My own slight indisposition however continues— My wife and family arrived
here on Monday, having stopped one day at Philadelphia, and been detained one day by the illness of Mary’s daughter Fanny, at Providence— We had an afternoon visit from William Lee— Joseph H. Adams was here; his mother is much indisposed— Mr and Mrs Lunt were also here this Evening.
20. V. Friday.

My indisposition continued all this day, and kept me confined to the house; feeble and almost helpless— Louisa C. Smith is here, having come out from Mr Foster’s last Tuesday with Charles— Mr Francis Jackson was here with his daughter. Charles and his wife were here more than once; and all their children, including the youngest Son, Henry Brooks, bornColl. Quincy was also here this Evening— His wife’s mother Mrs Miller is lying at the point of death at Boston; said to be with dropsy in the Chest— I had hoped to begin earnestly to retrieve my arrears of writing, this very day, but was disqualified for every thing, but lying on the bed.— I could not even visit my Son Charles and his wife at their new house, which they have occupied since their return from Washington— Mr Jackson gave me the small volume of Letters from the West-Indies, by Sylvester Hovey, Late Professor of Mathematics and Natural Philosophy, published by the Executive Committee of the American Union for the relief and improvement of the coloured race— Charles went to Boston—
21. V. Saturday—

My complaints are subsiding and passing away Morning visits from Mr Peter Whitney, and his second Son Frederick Augustus.— Mr Nathaniel Curtis was also here, and brought a deed of release to the proprietors of the Tremont Theatre, of a mortgage for 10000 dollars part of which has already been paid, and the remainder to be paid shortly. Mr Curtis and I executed this deed and our acknowledgment was taken by my Son, leaving the execution and acknowledgment still to be made by Mr. Boylston— Mr John Souther junr. Son of Captn John Souther of this town was here— He is a ship Carpenter, and has removed to Medford, where he is employed at work in his line of business— He proposes to settle there in permanent residence, and came to make enquiries with a view to the purchase of the Estate
there nominally belonging to me, but which my brother once owned, and conveyed to me, and which since his death I have held leaving all the rents and profits of it to the benefit of his widow— He said he had conversed on the subject with Mr John Angier her agent, who had referred him to me: and his enquiry was, whether the Estate was for sale, and if so at what price. I told him it would be for sale, if it could be sold profitably to Mrs Adams during her life; and to her children after her decease, as I held it only for their benefit— Mr and Mrs Edward Brooks with their Son and daughter were here this afternoon and from here went over to Charles’s house— I went there myself, and brought back with me the first volume of Ramsay’s history of the Revolution in South-Carolina— I had also examined Johnson’s Life of Nathaniel Greene, and found that in Stansbury’s Report of my Speech in the National Intelligencer, the Printers have transposed my quotations from those two works so as to annex my comment from one extract to the other and vice versa— A further blunder to be rectified in the pamphlet speech— Charles and his wife spent the Evening here.
22. IV:45. Sunday.

Dr Parkman preached this morning from 2. Peter 1.5. [“]And besides this, giving all diligence, add to your faith, virtue; and to virtue, knowledge; 6 And to knowledge, temperance; and to temperance patience; and to patience, godliness; 7. And to godliness brotherly kindness; and to brotherly kindness charity. 8— For if these things be in you and abound, they make you, that ye shall neither be barren nor unfruitful in the knowledge of our Lord Jesus Christ.”— Dr Parkman said that the word Virtue, should have been translated courage. In Charles Thomson’s translation it is Fortitude— Dr Parkman commented well upon the series of Virtues enumerated in this text; and also upon the import of the word abound. He dined with us, and his afternoon text was from 1. Timothy 2.1. [“]I exhort therefore, that, first of all, supplications, prayers, intercessions, and giving of thanks be made for all men; 2 For
kings, and for all that are in authority; that we may lead a quiet and peaceable life, in all godliness and honesty. 3. For this is good and acceptable in the sight of God our Saviour.” Dr Parkman’s Sermons are all exhortations to a kind, benevolent, affectionate morality.— Mr Degrand came out from Boston: dined and spent the day with us— After church, Mrs Angier from Medford was here with Mr Buttrick, and we had evening visits from Mr and Mrs Daniel Greenleaf; Mr G. W. Beale and his daughter Caroline; yet in mourning for her Sister Fanny, who died of consumption last Autumn after I went from home— Dr and Mrs Woodward who was Mary-Ann Greenleaf married also last October—and E. Price Greenleaf.— Charles and his wife were also here.— I read the 12th. Sermon of the 10th. Volume of Saurin on the destiny of the good and of the wicked.
23. V. Monday.

My health improves, but I am not yet able to set myself down to steady occupation— Joseph H. Adams here and this afternoon Ezra Dyer, who had many enquiries to make, concerning the pension-claim of his mother in Law the widow of Philip Thayer.— He said he had written to me three times concerning it and had received no answer; and he wished to know whether it would be necessary to present a new claim in her behalf under the recent act of Congress— I was not able to answer him, but requested him to call some day next week and promised to look up in the meantime all the information that I could obtain from an examination of my papers, and from a critical inspection of the new Widow’s Pension Law, which I have not yet received— This afternoon I took a ride with Charles, to Milton and Dorchester returning over the new road and Bridge called the Granite-Bridge over the Neponset river— The road passing from South of the Railway House to four Corners in Dorchester— Charles and his wife spent the Evening here— I visited my Garden and Nursery of trees this day;—after an absence from them of near eleven Months. The results of all my plantations are—Several Maple trees from Philadelphia seed sown 1. June 1835, flourishing beyond all comparison—one of the trees at least 12 feet high— Shagbark Hickory trees 5 years old—promising— A considerable number
of Peach-trees some of them well stocked with fruit— Here and there an Oak, from 2 years old to ten— A few equivocal Apple trees; and all the rest absolute failures, which I give up henceforth in despair.
24. IV:45. Tuesday

Morning visit from Captain John Whitney; who is this year the only representative of the town in the General Court— And afterwards from Captain Reilly with his Son who resides in the State of Ohio, and another Gentleman of the State, whose name he mentioned to me, but which I do not recollect— Captain Reilly talks much and is a man of much reflection and sagacity— But he is one of the most coarse and disgusting flatterers that I ever saw. It is impossible to endure him with Patience— He has found a purchaser of his wool, upon credit at Boston, and is going out again to Mogador— Charles went to Boston, but returned home to dinner, and with his wife spent the Evening here— This day the Mechanics of Boston and others gave a public dinner to Mr Daniel Webster in Faneuil Hall, at which upwards of sixteen hundred persons attended— I had received an invitation to it, but sent an excuse; being of opinion that such a dinner was no place for a man in the seventy-second year of his age— I wrote also to E. C. Prickett, Secretary of the Utica Anti-Slavery Society, and Alvan Stewart, Chairman of the Executive Committee of the New-York State Anti-Slavery Society, declining an invitation to attend, at Utica, the celebration of the 1st. of August, of the anniversary of the emancipation of the Slaves in the British Colonies— I have three such invitations for the same day— One at Utica—one at Boston, and one at Fall-river—
25 IV:15. Wednesday

Deacon William Spear was here this morning, and being the collector of taxes I gave him my Town and County, and my Parish tax, both of which are larger than they had ever been before (at least so is the Parish tax) to ascertain from the Assessors the particulars upon which they were made out. Mr P. C. Brooks had written a note to Charles saying that if the weather should be fair this day; he would come out and dine with him— Charles had invited me to be of his party— I dined with him— But
the weather this morning threatened to be foul, and was lowering the whole day— Mr Brooks did not come out— After dinner I took a ride with Charles round, by Braintree and Weymouth, returning by the way of the bridge and Turnpike— A Showy but not tasteful Mansion with front Pillars has arisen at the side of Solomon Thayer’s old and humble dwelling-house— We spent the Evening at Charles’s House— I began a preface for my pamphlet.
26. IV:30. Thursday.

Mr M’Coy is a stranger from Pittsburg Pennsylvania who called to see me for mere curiosity’s sake. An Anti-Mason, Anti-Slavery Ritner man, much concerned for the re-election of Governor Ritner, but very apprehensive that it will fail. Mr Tookey is a Boston Mechanic, who called also for curiosity, and told me that he had brought out his wife, who is out of health, to her fathers house, Mr Gay of this town— Afternoon visits from Dr and Mrs Follen— He has left New-York, and is now boarding at the house of Mrs Gile widow of a clergyman lately deceased at Milton— Mrs and Mrs Follen are abolitionists, and Anti-Slavery persons, of the highest tone— He told me that the population of the Island of Hayti, or Saint-Domingo, had increased since 1801. from 400000 to a million, or at leat to 900,000— Mr P. C. Brooks came out and dined with Charles and is to pass the Night there— After much of the day devoted to my preface, I walked over and we passed the Evening there— The light house at the entrance of Boston harbour, and that on long Island within the harbour, are conspicuous objects at Night, from Charles’s house— Wedding day
27 IV. Friday.

Mr Brooks was here yesterday this morning after breakfast, and walked with me round my garden Nursery and Seminary looking occasionally here and there at a tree— I have nothing to shew for all my toil and care and anxiety but my Philadelphia Maples, and a few scattering and yet miserably looking green peaches— The Althaeas before my Southern doors put forth their blossom cups this day, exactly a fortnight
earlier than the last and several preceding Seasons— Mr Brooks returned this morning to Boston and home.— Charles also went to Boston, and came home to dinner. Deacon Spear was here with a partial but insufficient explanation of my two tax bills by one of the Assessors— He took them back for a further explanation— A Mr St. Clair was here the whole afternoon; an agent of the State Anti-Slavery Society— Long and various conversation with him— He spoke of a public enquiry of my Sentiments as to the expediency of immediate abolition of Slavery in the District of Columbia— Enquired what would be the prospect of preventing the admission of a Slave State in Florida— Exceedingly sanguine as to the growth and spread of abolitionism— Thinks the abolitionists hold the balance of power now in all the free States; and that in six years they will have strength enough to abolish Slavery in the District— He said Isaac Knapp wished to give an order for 1000 copies of my pamphlet Speech, and I gave him the names of Gales and Seaton to whom he might apply for them— Mr Loring and the Revd. Charles Brooks of Hingham were here— Invited me to a fishing party there next Thursday; with Charles—to be at Mr Loring’s at 7. O’Clock A.M.— Mr Brooks had written to me, repeating an invitation that I would attend a meeting of the American Institute of Instruction at Lowell, the week before Commencement, and deliver an Address upon Education—which I was under the necessity of again declining— Mr E. Price Greenleaf was here; and returned a Volume of Spanish Laws— Evening visit from Mr Edward Miller with his Son Charles— The leisure of the day was occupied with my preface, but these visitors took so much time that I made little progress— No exercise— Charles and his wife spent the Evening here.
28. III:30. Saturday
Mrs. Armstrong.

Restless Night—perhaps over anxious about the Speech.— Walk over the hills. Saw the Sunrise from the Eastern end of Charles’s House— Finished my Preface and the revisal of the Tohu Bohu report in the National Intelligencer of my fragments of the 28th. of June. And I answered the invitation of Edmund Quincy, to the celebration by the State Anti-Slavery Society at Boston, of the British Slave emancipation
emancipation anniversary on the 1st. of August—declined Attending— Mr and Mrs Armstrong paid us a morning visit— Mr. Armstrong read my answer to the invitation to the Webster dinner—and gave a complimentary toast; for which I was not warm enough in my return of thanks— He spoke of my recent Speech and said he had enquired of H. G. Otis, where I had taken the allusion to Arria and and that Mr Otis had after some examination referred him to Pliny— I had myself forgotten where it was to be found— It is in Pliny’s Epistles Book 3— Ep. 16. In Martial’s Epigrams—in the Tatler and in Rees’s Encyclopaedia— Mr Armstrong said Mr Otis had been much struck with the remark that the Resurrection of Lazarus was performed at the Petition of a Woman— Mary, and Charles’s wife and the three little girls went this afternoon to Boston, and returned at the dusk of Evening— Heat of the day very oppressive Charles here this Evening
29. III:30. Sunday.

Another suffocating Night— I went to bed last Night with a head ache, and awoke with one this Morning before 3. O’Clock. I rose at 4. walked over the hill, and saw the sun rise clear from Charles’s House— Then came home, and prepared a Letter for W. W. Seaton with the preface, and sundry slips of the Intelligencer for my pamphlet. Mr Lunt preached this morning from Hebrews 13.2 “Be not forgetful to entertain strangers: for thereby some have entertained angels, unawares.” upon the duties of hospitality, and some original fanciful explanations of the prospect of entertaining angels— His afternoon Sermon was from Colossians 2.14. “And above all these things put on charity, which is the bond of perfectness.” He gave notice that the communion would be administered next Sunday— While we were at dinner there was a very heavy thunder shower, the cloud being immediately over our heads— From the sound of one of the claps of thunder, the lightening must have fallen very near us.— But it cleared off immediately after, and the atmosphere was as heated as before— Charles and his wife
spent the Evening here— I read the 13th. and last Sermon of Saurin of the 10th. Volume; on the Wisdom of Solomon. He takes for his text the 3d. chapter of the 1st. book of Kings, from the 5th. to the 14th. verse, tells the whole Story of the vision of Solomon at Gibeon, and descants upon it largely.— As is very common with this writer he perplexes himself with difficulties, without very well knowing how to solve them— He enquires how it happened that with this preternatural gift of wisdom from above, he could in his old age so wretchedly fall off, with 700. Princess wives and 300 concubines into Idolatry? And after putting this question he does not very satisfactorily answer it— I changed my bedchamber this Evening for my Library—to breathe fresh air.
30. IV:30. Monday

There is an oppression upon my Spirits which with the unusual intenseness of the Summer heat almost deprives me of sleep— Last night however with the benefit of open windows I awoke not until the morning dawn, and barely rose before the Sun— I had to answer a Letter from Miss Anna Quincy Thaxter Sat down to write it in five lines, and wrote it in four pages, occupying all the morning till dinner— It led me to a partial examination of the copies of my mother’s Letters in her own hand writing; and that to meditation upon the severe, Oh! how severe trials, with which she was afflicted, in her earthly career, and with what bleeding sensibility, and with what Spartan Fortitude, and with what Saint like Resignation she endured them! What a Lesson to her children was her whole Life! and how imperfectly, and ineffectually have I profited by it!— This afternoon two Mr Smith’s came out from Boston, to urge me to deliver the introductory Lecture to the course of the Boston Lyceum to commence some time next October— Of these applications I believe I have on hand nearly twenty; most of which I have declined; and to comply with some of which I have made conditional promises.— I could not give an absolute negative now; and promised to deliver the Lecture, if I should find myself able to do it, with another engagement, if I should finally decline, to give them notice, in season to supply the place, by another Lecturer— Charles and his wife spent the Evening
with us— The Sun was so scorching the whole day that I did not venture out of the House; but in the Evening the atmosphere cooled with the Northwestern breeze nearly to a chill— Received a letter from Dr Mease of Philadelphia with copies of the papers relating to the Patriotic exertions of the Ladies of Philadelphia in 1780. which he had promised me— The Letter from General Washington to the Ladies which he had read to me is in Sparks’s collection of his writings Vol. 7. p. 408—and two other Letters from Washington, on the same subject—one p. 89. to President Reed, and one p 376. to Mrs Sarah Bache. Besides one to Mrs. Mary Lee p. 243. relating to the contributions of the women of Baltimore— I had thoughts of referring to all this in an Appendix to the pamphlet Speech; but think best on reflection to reserve it for a reply to Howard who will make a very elaborate effort to answer me at the next Session of Congress.
31. IV:15. Tuesday.

Walk to Charles’s house and marked the rising of the Sun, over the summit of Hough’s Neck— About 7. A.M went with Charles, and bathed and swam about 5 minutes at Daniel Greenleaf’s creek.— Prepared the slips of the Intelligencer from 6 to 10. inclusive for the publication of the pamphlet, and wrote to W. W. Seaton. Deacon William Spear, brought me a specification of my Parish tax Bill; but not that of the Town and County tax— The Assessors fleece me without mercy; but whoever is or has been prosperous in the world must submit to much injustice and oppression especially from tax gatherers—with whom it’s always odious to have any disagreement. The Deacon informed me that the County Commissioners have staked out another road to pass through my lot which I purchased of James Baxter— David Loud was here and enquired about Letters which he says he wrote me, and a power of Attorney which he sent me to recover a quarter of Section of Soldier’s Land due for his Son Warren Loud, in the State of Arkansas, for military service in the late War— I found on my file of last Winter a Letter from this David Loud, unanswered, referring to the former Letter and power, but these I did not find, and have a very indistinct recollection of what I did with or about them.— I was obliged to ask him to come again some time next week; promising to search in the meantime for his Letter and Power— Alpheus Spear came and
settled with me for his rent for three Quarters from 30. September to 30 June last— But he has yet to settle for 3. years parish taxes— Mr Loring and Miss Anna Quincy Thaxter were here—adding to the invitation to the fishing party on Thursday, another invitation to a tea-party of the Ladies in the Evening, to which Miss Thaxter invited also our Ladies— Ezra Dyer came again about the pension for his mother in Law, the widow of Philip Thayer— I had got the pension-Law of the last Session but was still unconscious of what had been done in this case— Dyer will call again on Friday or Saturday next— After he was gone I found an answer from the Commissioner of Pensions, dated in March last, to an application in behalf of Mrs Thayer— From the Answer it would seem that her case is one of those provided for by the Law of the last Session. Ebenezer Adams was here and repeated the information of the road laid out by the County Commissioners through my Baxter lot— He promised to call again at an early day and take me with him to view it— I took my Spy-glass over to Charles’s House and spent the Evening there. Mr and Mrs Lunt, Mary, and Louisa C. Smith were there—200 paces from my gate to his. Cool Morn and Eve—warm day.

Rise between 4 and 5—and have seen almost every day the Sun rise clear for almost six weeks— The two-Months of June and July have been of the most intense heat that I ever experienced— Since the adjournment of Congress, besides the three days in which I came from Washington, my serious occupations have been to revise first the Notes of the Reporters of my running Speech of three weeks for the National Intelligencer, and then to revise them all again for the pamphlet publication— My amusements have in a great measure vanished— The heat of the weather debars me from my usual waste of time heretofore in my garden, and so many of my seedling trees have perished that I give up that pursuit in despair, or at least in the conviction that it cannot be successful to a man who from five to eleven Months of the year is absent from his plantation— I am now surrounded by many comforts enjoyments, leaving me only the conviction of a duty daily and hourly pressing upon me with increasing gravity to prepare for my own transition to another world, and to pray for the welfare, virtue and happiness of those I am to leave behind—
